title: Area Four: Health and Physical Development
subject: Early Learning and Development Standards (2021-)

document.title: VIRGINIA’S EARLY LEARNING & DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS (ELDS): BIRTH-FIVE LEARNING GUIDELINES

53097829AAA646EE9973D899934F404E.description:
Can describe why
sleep keeps us healthy

633C762B2AE94C51916DDDF83B1E9AF8.description:
Independently starts
and participates in sleep
routines (HPD4.4m)

E39A9A7CE102436AA52439F2772D4E9D.description:
Recognizes when they
are tired and tells an adult

87DCC3F33A674F50AB29EE50E1E60055.description:
With increasing
independence, starts
and participates in sleep
routines to calm the body
and prepare for sleeping

C2005034A5E64800B48F21B663C04D7A.description:
Indicates they are tired
by saying, “I’m sleepy.”

50B60AA3B2F94329A4FF0CBC84FD3229.description:
Participates in sleep
routines with guidance

5286D2CAFF88474791A509EC4F7430C4.description:
Sleeps well, wakes up
rested and ready for daily
activities

B560DDE256F946BDA90343CC869CFA3F.description:
Sleeps more
consistently and shows
alertness when awake

4F5000E9EEA14E7C810FA2FFF746774F.description:
Responds to verbal
cues like “it’s time to
take a nap” by snuggling
favorite sleep toy; takes
several naps during the
day

A4B06CCAF12F4C14AA2202D62338D9C7.description:
Settles down and falls
asleep after a familiar
sleep routine (e.g., story
and song before napping)

EC005B950E614F03972A206151534C70.description:
Sleeps for longer
periods at a time and
starts to have longer
night-time sleep periods

E1FEAA7AE98C4C6A926F40253773F11E.description:
Begins to sleep well
and shows alertness when
awake

F3DE1A39A3C24965B1EDA5BA7C3485CA.description: Developing healthy habits for rest and sleep

507148A6F0864BE7941D8B65132D08C4.description:
Demonstrates an
increasing understanding
of the ways in which
healthy food helps the
body grow, like saying,
“Milk makes my bones
strong.”

5CE81787CC5247B598E5E409309716A2.description:
Follows picture recipes
to prepare a simple snack

A445DF1FFCA443F2A613B5E1048462BD.description:
Makes healthy
eating choices both
independently and with
support

F61BD1F1015C48C28D724DF540AEAFE4.description:
Identifies a variety of
healthy and unhealthy
foods, sorting pictures
of food by color or as
“always” and “sometimes”
foods

41B07252939D47B995A98E80DE2859CB.description:
Helps prepare
nutritious snacks,
serving self and others

6BD00C70F74544E8A6FBFC4915AC0580.description:
Identifies at least 1 fruit
and 1 vegetable; explains
that fruits and vegetables
help our bodies move

01C333AB60234E1BAC694FBBE98EE718.description:
Explains that food
provides energy for
movement

8B0EF2594F674B2CB187827289595AE3.description:
Prepares nutritious
snacks with adult
assistance by stirring and
using measuring cups

4921F8867D3745668C6145D91E46A4BA.description:
Eats a variety of
nutritious foods and
recognizes healthy foods

019ADEE855224ECFA5341DAA9B8554A9.description:
Begins to distinguish
between food and nonfood items

DB22C8812FED4372AB72523042812D19.description:
Shows interest in new
foods that are offered

A11A3A774CE646F29A72B4B8B3A33343.description:
May begin to eat food
with fingers, like small
pieces of papaya and
mango

DD960982ECBF491E8D1041CC843D0AD7.description:
Sucks and swallows
liquids from breast or
bottle

241FABA7D256488A9BA5024FC55E8EE5.description:
Identifies people in the
community who can help
them (e.g., firefighter,
nurse)

730BDA589065460BA615624C197C3B1D.description:
Participates in safety
practices by helping to
use car seat restraints and
helmets

C7429ADAE16543C8B99362AF7542D7CA.description:
Follows basic safety
rules, signs, and labels
consistently and
anticipates consequences
of not following rules

7E61E48B567B442C8C8404EB3BA59310.description:
Identifies medicines
and other household
substances that can be
harmful

63759A629DE24F80B0B7C59601631B42.description:
Demonstrates safe
behaviors by participating
appropriately during
physical activity,
accepting feedback, and
taking responsibility for
behavior when prompted

57B646306D6B4F059EF1ED03430EEEB6.description:
Tells a trusted adult
when someone gets hurt

22894DD23E994471B8E9470D32E05158.description:
Tells peers and
adults when dangerous
situations are observed

5A586DCA4DBC42FFA8ADB534B76242EA.description:
Shows awareness of
a growing number of
personal safety practices
and routines; looks
to adults for support
in enacting these;
participates in safety drills

EA362F252603416CA1B312AD1365E485.description:
Pays attention to
simple safety instructions

BCFBCE3466CE498EAEE3CD23D8AE3A4F.description:
Learns some differences
between safe and unsafe
play behaviors (e.g., not
standing on chairs or
tables)

600A53EF244F46FE96AF1BE8F652B119.description:
Accepts adult guidance,
support, and protection
when encountering
unsafe situations

249EAAA3119344208D8964A828534F73.description:
Watches for adult
reactions to unfamiliar
people or situations

471103A5AF8B498CA6882C39248D8C41.description:
Cooperates with
safety instructions and
warnings (e.g., holding
a caregiver’s hand)

21DAF7003E8344E59CC01FBEC034AE7F.description:
Reacts to simple
directions that support
safety (e.g., washing
hands after diaper
changes)

64F253330D3B41DDBFCCD9AEC2630ACA.description:
Seeks physical contact
with primary caregivers
when faced with new
or unfamiliar people or
environments

A26A167B27A04881820A5DC096997502.description:
Responds to verbal
or physical signals of
danger with a cry or
reach towards primary
caregiver

D246171C465243DEAE92890B6205A273.description:
Cries to indicate
stress and to seek help

127957085CE54A4DAEAAF95349181585.description:
Consistently uses
strategies to calm
themselves when needed

E546FE4B89D04E2C81E344185C981DCC.description:
Uses language to
ask adults or peers for
the help needed in a
particular situation,
including acting out
stories or in play scenes

96216FC8FDEB4BF4B41F7338213B3CFB.description:
Takes more
responsibility for personal
hygiene and self-care
skills (e.g., washing
hands independently)

0C416A0C85114EFCBDA6AAC87719B55D.description:
Understands need for
good dental hygiene,
including brushing teeth

33793BD3A68C44A4833744421254B90C.description:
Uses a variety of
strategies to calm
themselves (e.g.,
changing activities,
getting a comfort object)

AE7836EFE1A24F0CABB852FCBE3E580A.description:
Uses language to ask
adults or peers for help
needed to start a zipper
or turn on water to wash
hands

F2E6AA333C744017AAEDE55F9C29F20A.description:
Begins to take care
of personal health
needs and self-care
needs independently by
washing hands after using
the toilet

D2B283BF2D244160860EBF55A6EF6817.description:
Describes ways to
participate in physical
activity and provides
alternatives to screen time

714B6DCF25CC4457AAC5B14B697EA557.description:
Identifies places
at home, in the
neighborhood, and in
the community where
children can play safely
and be physically active

357FACFAC0D04A9C879CC4B74F6A66F7.description:
Begins to use different
strategies to calm
themselves when needed
(e.g., seeks out a quiet
space)

18AB78CB11CC43759411D5B7DEF6CC8D.description:
Uses words or sign
language to ask for what
they need (e.g., food
when hungry, drink
when thirsty)

2186EED90E584C35BAC198B777A87703.description:
Takes care of personal
self-care needs like handwashing with some adult
assistance

847EFC94D322413DAEA73FECB93653AB.description:
Soothes themselves
when needed (e.g., looks
at book before nap)

F63720FB7BA74341B23BC1336DE3640F.description:
Uses gestures, words,
or sign language to
communicate what they
need

4C89F28BA2FB46138C5ACC738E53E715.description:
Cooperates and helps
with care routines
(e.g., dental care, handwashing)

F0EA8B8A4C484CEF9092D5F45538A498.description:
Shows trust in familiar
caregivers (e.g., calms
down with adult help)

ED664DC4C92F4ABCB9C7C6C1E84B116B.description:
Uses gestures, sounds,
or sign language to
communicate need for
food, drink, or diaper
change

1DC82792C3B74E7DAB29E41876B52E85.description:
Cooperates in daily
routines, such as opens
mouth for spoon or
toothbrush, or raises arms
for dressing

829237AB08F247BEBCA2CA410ED83B7F.description:
Communicates needs
for comfort and care

952D199C442C464389A28D458797948D.description:
Cooperates in care
routines (e.g., diapering,
hand-washing, dressing,
and brushing gums)

C9E710DCA9144613B42AB97BAB12BA49.description: Taking care of daily health needs

C64216516C5C4676998D490742DEC121.description:
Manages self-help
routines such as dressing
self (e.g., zipping,
buttoning, snapping)

1D70A36B9038428E914CBEFFEE7F73A8.description:
Draws with crayons
and markers and cuts
with scissors, with
moderate levels of
precision and control
(e.g., cuts along a line or
circle)

AE2EDEA894DC4778904F2C0E0D43D54B.description:
Uses scissors to cut
along a straight line
and circle, with some
precision (within 1/2” to
1/4” of line)

57E210B85F694D5A851D43F678EBB154.description:
Adjusts grasp to
use different tools for
different purposes, such
as a spoon and marker

A57128E520254D73880CE450EE8EBC33.description:
Plans ways to use hands
for various activities, such
as stacking, building,
connecting, drawing

1364641238144A06933832AD294E2138.description:
Extends reach by
using simple tools such
as a stick or rake to pull
a distant object closer

D36F1BE506294C41922DB7B97E80DA32.description:
Uses hands and fingers
to build a tall block
tower, turns single book
pages, twists toy nuts and
bolts, uses one hand to
hold and drink from a
cup

3F7332EB0945489A91A6EF2362570126.description:
Matches grasp to the
task such as using an
index finger and thumb
to pick up pieces of cereal
while using the whole
hand to bang items
together

3F50DA36F4F14DA29D9E3A172CD19EF0.description:
Explores properties
of objects and materials
by using various hand
actions, such as picking
them up to examine
them; enjoys playing
with manipulatives and
materials of various
shapes and textures

AC4641AA6F1A4403A85D51B9D1D4FF9A.description:
Uses full hand to grab
items to explore (e.g.,
picks up toy, holds
onto an adult’s finger)

068C585FE0A3426A997373A2C2371CD5.description:
Uses single actions
to explore shape, size,
texture, or weight of
objects, such as turning
an object over or around

6FD3B35A6F9447C6BB5D7B1F88A11D49.description:
Draws smaller figures
and includes more detail
(e.g., faces with features)

A33A06405DB8468B9AE7F7A98ECF085D.description:
Uses objects with ease
(e.g., fork, spoon, and
sometimes a table knife)

9318A5E93BEF4017B4606F1762ED9169.description:
Uses tools that require
strength, control, and
skills of small muscles
such as a fork and scissors

D781669A31E54845A2B7ECF8C8D4FD75.description:
Draws simple shapes
and figures (square,
circle) and copies
straight lines and circles

208F001DFC9B4816AE23F7E7692AE99F.description:
Plays with smaller
objects with increasing
control

D4CB84D2946E4AEC811E71E6BA9B29F8.description:
Uses tools that require
finger and hand control
(e.g., painting with a
large paintbrush, holding
eating utensils, buttoning
clothes)

D95355A77D7048989915A3F53FD95075.description: Uses simple tools (e.g., spoon, play hammer, crayon)

61D17F63E1A24D67A8A6A0DA50AF0DF8.description:
Plays with objects
such as putting together
and taking apart toys

EB150B95C6824D5FA294078F594E26E6.description:
Performs more
complex actions such as
transferring objects from
one hand to the other
and dropping them into a
container

98D51B08BB22434AA0D55E251EA8A12E.description:
Uses both hands to
swipe at, reach for, grasp,
hold, shake, release
objects, and begins to
transfer objects from
hand to hand

E3ADED2015794D649216F9B08FAC6848.description:
Coordinates hands
and eyes when reaching
for and holding items

4292966BCA314BAA8DFD4EF22FF6485F.description:
Develops strength and
stamina by spending
extended periods of
time playing and
participating in activities
that build strength,
speed, flexibility, and
coordination (e.g., tag,
red light - green light)

5EAD8CC70ABF4C1B800B0B2601A50C40.description:
Chooses to participate
in simple games and
other structured motor
activities (indoor and
outdoor) that enhance
physical fitness, such as
songs with movement,
throwing and catching
balls

7587BC7A53E4440B85B5EA9AB0E48B8E.description:
Uses a variety of
increasingly complex
movements and body
positions to participate
in active and quiet
indoor and outdoor play

2C4C1C0662E942D186370792871B2BE7.description:
Shows enjoyment of
active play and engages
in regular and sustained
movement (e.g., pushes
toys around, goes up
and down slide over and
over, dumps items out of
containers)

2883D26F833C45209A5A68ADCCEF2A6C.description:
Uses body position,
balance, and movement
to explore and examine
materials, activities, and
to move in environments
(e.g., pulling up to stand
holding on to couch,
cruising around tables)

2FD0D95EC4C24D2BB761E91AD6452C1B.description:
Uses each new position
(raising head, rolling
onto back, sitting)
to learn new ways to
explore the environment,
(e.g., sits up to be able
to reach for an object)

67786F819B754E988B298D7FD5153C89.description:
Shows awareness
of one's own body in
relation to other people
and objects while moving
or dancing through space
and at varying speeds and
levels

B152A6B626B04BC682580C39D2900BFF.description:
Carries out activities
that combine and
coordinate large muscle
movements, including
swinging on a swing,
climbing a ladder,
dancing to music, or
balancing on one leg for
longer periods of time

6970B440D83A427F8AEAA163405DB639.description:
Demonstrates more
coordinated movement
when jumping for height
and distance, hopping,
and running

DAC36863E70043E28C2897BCB34B63E3.description:
Uses a variety of toys
and equipment that
enhance gross motor
skills and coordination
(e.g., throws and catches
balls, climbs up steps to a
slide)

86C1B5377B9A4F95ACC685AE1CC16DD2.description:
Demonstrates strength
and balance by managing
uneven surfaces such as
hills, ramps, and steps

5CDDD2526B954E529C5313682F2B5D30.description:
Moves body in space
with good coordination
(e.g., running, hopping
in place, galloping)

7940B6EFCE634DF5B6C36C4DCAAE0115.description:
Understands that
physical fitness is
important and identifies
activities they enjoy
doing with their family

EC4890F4EDC24C39BA9F5A65D91E12A5.description:
Identifies parts of the
body that help us move
and understands how
movement leads to a rise
in heart and breathing
rates

06628F9CA6784370A7050BAE26CF206F.description:
Performs actions
smoothly with
balance, strength, and
coordination (e.g.,
dances, bends over to
pick up a toy, reaches
up high on a shelf, walks
up and down steps)

03EF22C7C74E495CB3F12DC09ED96598.description:
Uses familiar objects
that encourage large
motor movements (e.g.,
riding toys, crawl tubes,
slides)

01AB30B19D6746DD96CBF875DA0D666B.description:
Gains control of a
variety of movements
including running and
jumping with increasing
independence

AE640FCD27AB47C7BCDE878408297761.description:
Develops strength,
balance, and coordination
by repeating movements
(e.g., walks up and down
stairs while holding on,
climbs onto furniture,
and begins to run)

2C5F23E07DEC4D639F5A3ED41961BFE0.description:
Moves through
the world with more
independence

43844A0551D149D9A08008FB6BAB65BB.description:
Moves around in
their environment by
pulling to stand, cruising,
and standing alone

6A99AB105D91449C824FC48F0D50F945.description:
Manages moving
around on different types
of surfaces, like carpet
and grass

C20EAB7F29164A2693DDFD156370578B.description:
Moves from crawling
to standing to cruising to
walking, learning new
muscle coordination for
each new skill

CAAE8492A2B94101822CAFD934678C2C.description:
Explores new body
positions and movements,
such as rolling over,
sitting, scooting,
crawling, hitting, or
kicking at objects while
lying on back

929C8238088B4EEC94850F7FDDCCA803.description:
Shows increasing
awareness of body, space,
and relationship to other
objects to allow more
coordinated movements,
actions, and interactions
with others (e.g., shows
the ability to get in line
with other children and
walk in line)

2D5B4AEA72B94C22A2AF8E8128A18669.description:
Uses sensory
information to guide
motions and interactions
with objects and other
people (e.g., plays games
like tag with other
children)

222AC5831D7E4CABAF03872F05254BD6.description:
Learns about ways
to protect sensory
body parts (e.g., wears
helmets to protect heads,
gloves to protect hands,
and headphones for
listening to protect ears)

F33EEE020E3A49569FCFE05B0DA5DCFF.description:
Shows some awareness
of one's own body, space,
and relationship to other
objects (e.g., jumps three
times and then turns
around without bumping
into a peer or other
object)

2C00ED1641B44238A359A662AA45DAC9.description:
Develops the ability
to use one sense to
predict what they would
perceive with another
(e.g., realizes food is hot
or cold)

6CCDD747B5704038B009A584F736EB14.description:
Shows increased
balance and coordination
in play activities and daily
routines, such as playing
a game or singing a
song with hand motions

2D5D10D4BB1B492C8056AAF8041C89AB.description:
Shows understanding
of body size, such as doll
clothes will not fit on a
child’s body or a child’s
body will not fit on doll
furniture

12B1B651F76E4729A594A06E2FD3EF56.description:
Uses the information
received from their senses
to guide interactions
with the environment
(e.g., notices that adults
put on coats before going
outside and then goes
to get their own coat)

D57E29B3489C4CEAB67BAFF9546E4CED.description:
Combines information
from the senses to inform
the way they interact
with the environment
and acquire information
(e.g., touches a variety
of objects during walk)

D90AA4D2435449E99DCD8CD9EE320285.description:
Demonstrates sensory
preferences (e.g., chooses
clothes of a particular
color or enjoys putting
their feet in sand or grass)

87AA8C8F70F54C13BE7728CAC1949C2D.description:
Uses touch to learn
about different textures
in the environment (e.g.,
touches grass with hands
when outside, sticky
foods)

26A7AEDA0E7B496890E8E620B495DC73.description:
Uses depth perception,
scans for obstacles, and
plans movement while
learning to scoot, crawl,
walk or move in another
way

281C114F81834B9D85936A80193F3C57.description:
Shows awareness
as an accomplished
crawler or walker of new
challenges or dangers in
the environment, such as
steep inclines or drop-offs

EAA2445D0B9D4C2ABF04B375A74727D9.description:
Understands properties
of objects in matching
and associates them with
each other through play
and interaction (e.g., uses
a bottle to feed a baby)

1AC54EA39A904BC19907D0E5DEA75D81.description:
Uses oral sensory
exploration to learn about
the environment and for
soothing

859B75650E9745FCA0665F80077E0A08.description:
Adjusts balance and
movement with the
changing size and
proportion of their body
(e.g., rolls over and
moves from sitting to
crawling or scooting)

BD61F84768FA4CB4B76D65522382A7A4.description:
Turns head or body in
the direction of a sound
to learn more about
the environment (e.g.,
a young infant turns
toward an adult and
repositions their body to
be picked up)

33B6D33ADA894B8B89BBFB768EC8B1BB.description:
Uses their senses
to explore objects
and people in the
environment
